input: What is Q-in-Q?
output: Q-in-Q, also known as 802.1ad, is a protocol commonly used by network service providers to provide more Layer 2 flexibility. It allows multiple VLAN tags to be inserted into a single Ethernet frame.

input: Why is Q-in-Q used?
output: Q-in-Q is used to isolate routing domains and provide a way to identify and separate customer traffic within a service provider network. It allows for more efficient and flexible Layer 2 networking.

input: What are the EtherTypes used in Q-in-Q?
output: Under the 802.1ad standard, the inner VLAN tag commonly uses EtherType 0x8100 and the outer VLAN tag uses 0x88a8. However, the default configuration for most network vendors' Q-in-Q is for both inner and outer EtherTypes to be 0x8100.

input: How does Q-in-Q work with Megaport VXCs?
output: Megaport VXCs are point-to-point Layer 2 circuits that can be configured with VLAN tags. With Q-in-Q, the customer traffic VLAN tags (C-Tags) are inserted inside the service provider VLAN tags (S-Tags) provided by Megaport. This allows for the transfer of multiple VLANs over a single VXC.

input: What are some alternatives to Q-in-Q?
output: If your routers or switches don't support Q-in-Q, you can consider alternatives such as configuring a single Azure peering VLAN, untagging the VXC attached to the customer port, or deploying a Megaport Cloud Router (MCR) to handle the Q-in-Q requirements.

input: How can I configure a single Azure peering VLAN?
output: You can configure the VXC so that Megaport removes the Q-in-Q requirement by remapping one of the B-End VLAN IDs for Private Peering or Microsoft Peering to the customer Megaport-facing VLAN. However, with this configuration, you can only use a single Microsoft peering type per VXC.

input: What is the drawback of untagging the VXC?
output: By configuring the VXC as untagged, the S-Tag is automatically removed. However, this limits the port to a single VXC connection, meaning you can only configure a single B-End target. It also means that your port will receive all inner VLAN tags as single/dot1q tagged.

input: How does deploying a Megaport Cloud Router help with Q-in-Q?
output: By deploying a Megaport Cloud Router (MCR), you can automate the handling of Q-in-Q requirements for one or both peering types. However, this comes with additional cost for the MCR and an additional VXC to the MCR.

input: What happens with Q-in-Q when connecting to Microsoft ExpressRoute?
output: When connecting to Microsoft ExpressRoute, the VXCs may contain one or two inner VLAN tags (C-Tags). These inner tags are configured in the Microsoft Azure console and are required for the ExpressRoute connection. Network equipment that supports Q-in-Q can access these inner tags by stripping the outer VLAN tag (S-Tag).

input: Can I use more than one peering type with the single Azure peering VLAN configuration?
output: No, with the single Azure peering VLAN configuration, only one peering type (private or Microsoft) is supported per VXC. If you need to use both peering types, you will need to configure two separate VXCs.

input: How does configuring the VXC as untagged affect the VLAN tags?
output: By configuring the VXC as untagged, the outer VLAN (S-Tag) is removed, and the inner VLAN tags (C-Tags) are presented to the customer Megaport. This allows for the transparent transfer of the inner VLAN tags without the need for Q-in-Q settings on the customer device.

input: What is the Megaport Cloud Router (MCR)?
output: The Megaport Cloud Router (MCR) is a solution that enables multi-cloud and multi-region connectivity. It supports Q-in-Q and can be used to connect to multiple cloud destinations. The MCR manages the S-Tags (outer tags) and transparently carries the C-Tags, allowing for efficient and flexible network connections.

input: Is it possible to have multiple Azure VXCs on an MCR with the same VLAN tags?
output: Yes, if you have multiple Azure VXCs on an MCR, you can populate the same VLAN tags for private peering and public peering. The MCR will manage the Q-in-Q tunnel for each Azure VXC, and each Azure VLAN will be treated as a separate logical interface.

input: What are the limitations of the Single Azure Peering VLAN option?
output: The Single Azure Peering VLAN option allows you to specify a single Azure peering VLAN for the VXC. However, it only supports one peering type (private or Microsoft) per VXC. If you need to use both peering types, you will need to configure two separate VXCs.

input: Can I have multiple peering types on a single ExpressRoute circuit pair?
output: No, Microsoft currently does not support the segmentation of bandwidth between multiple peering types on a single ExpressRoute circuit pair. If you need to have multiple peering types, it is recommended to deploy two ExpressRoute pairs.

input: Are there any recommended workarounds for handling Q-in-Q frames?
output: While there are workarounds such as handling Q-in-Q frames at the customer side with multiple devices or using loopback cables within a single device, these are generally not recommended in production networks.

input: What is the purpose of Q-in-Q in Azure ExpressRoute?
output: In Azure ExpressRoute, Q-in-Q is used to carry multiple C-Tags/inner VLANs within a single S-Tag/outer VXC VLAN. It allows for the encapsulation and transfer of customer traffic across the ExpressRoute circuit.

input: How can I enable the Single Azure Peering VLAN functionality in Megaport?
output: To enable the Single Azure Peering VLAN functionality in Megaport, you can select the option in the Connection Details panel of a new ExpressRoute connection. You can specify a single Azure peering VLAN, which will be matched with the value configured in the Azure ExpressRoute configuration.

input: What happens if I leave the Preferred A-End VLAN field blank?
output: If you leave the Preferred A-End VLAN field blank, a randomly chosen VLAN will be assigned to your VXC when you place the order. If you enter a VLAN, a validation check will be performed to ensure its availability.

output: Yes, it is possible to use different VLAN tags for the primary and secondary Microsoft ExpressRoute endpoints on a given ExpressRoute circuit. This can be used to achieve zonal diversity or split the primary/secondary connections across two Megaport-enabled locations.

input: What should I check for when troubleshooting a Port that is down or flapping?

input: How can interface statistics and device logs help in identifying the cause of a fault?
output: Interface statistics and device logs can provide valuable information about the fault. For example, increasing incoming errors on a network interface may indicate a potential issue with other components of the cross connect, rather than a specific SFP. Analyzing these statistics and logs can help narrow down the root cause.

input: What tests should be performed by the data center to verify physical connections?
output: The data center should perform tests to check the cross connect for damages or cleaning, if needed. Additionally, they should measure the light transmission at the demarcation point using a light reading meter.

input: Are there any specific checks to be done for the carrier circuit status?
output: Yes, when verifying the carrier circuit status, you should ensure that the device interfaces in the cross connect path are free of errors. Also, check that the transmit and receive optical levels are operating correctly. This will help ensure that the carrier circuit is functioning properly.

input: What should I include when contacting support for further assistance?

input: What are the Megaport Technical Specifications for SFP models?

input: What is the purpose of checking for CRC errors and packet drops?

input: What does it mean if a Port is rapidly alternating between an up/down state (flapping)?
output: If a Port is rapidly alternating between an up/down state (flapping), it means that the Port is not stable and is experiencing frequent disruptions in traffic flow. This can be caused by various factors such as physical connection issues, configuration problems, or faulty network devices.

input: What does it mean to have transmit and receive optical levels operating correctly?

input: Why is it important to provide troubleshooting results when contacting support?

input: What is the purpose of route filtering?
output: Route filtering provides selective control over which networks are discoverable between BGP neighbor routers, influencing routing paths, managing redundancy, and improving security.

input: How can route filtering be used?
output: Route filtering can be used to redistribute or prevent redistribution of routes between Virtual Cross Connects (VXCs), create BGP prefix filters, and allow or deny specific routes on specific connections.

input: What type of routes are advertised without filters?

input: What is the default behavior of MCR without route filters?

input: How does BGP peer filtering work?
output: BGP peer filtering permits or denies route exchange between BGP neighbors, providing a way to filter routes based on specific neighbor configurations.

input: What are the possible actions for a BGP peer filter?
output: The possible actions for a BGP peer filter are default (follows the source peering type policy), permit (allows route advertisements), and deny (prevents route advertisements).

input: What is Salesforce Express Connect?

input: How can I create a network connection from an MVE to AWS?

input: What are the requirements before creating a connection to AWS?

input: What are the two models of VXC connections to AWS?
output: The two models of VXC connections to AWS are Hosted Connections and Hosted Virtual Interfaces (Hosted VIFs). Hosted Connections are dedicated connections, while Hosted VIFs can connect to public or private AWS cloud services.

input: How is creating a connection to AWS from the MVE different from creating it from a Port or an MCR?
output: The primary difference is that the process with Aruba SD-WAN does not automatically configure the MVE in Aruba. You need to manually create a LAN interface and define VLANs, IP addresses, MD5 values, and BGP peers in the Aruba Orchestrator console.

input: Can a Hosted Connection support multiple virtual interfaces?
output: No, a Hosted Connection can support only one private, public, or transit virtual interface.

input: What is the recommended connection type for production environments?
output: Hosted Connections are the recommended connection type for production environments.

input: What type of connections do Hosted VIFs share bandwidth with?
output: Hosted VIFs share bandwidth with other Hosted VIF connections.

input: What does Aruba Orchestrator allow you to do in the connection setup?

output: There is no specific order, but you need to ensure that all components are properly configured before creating a connection to AWS.

input: Can a Hosted VIF connect to a transit virtual interface?

input: Are Hosted Connections dedicated connections?

output: MCR supports non-cloud, private cloud, and public cloud peering types.

output: The routes advertised by the non-cloud peering type are from the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) peer behind a Port.

input: What cloud service providers can be connected through the MCR?
output: MCR can connect to cloud service providers such as AWS, Azure, Oracle, and other Cloud Service Providers (CSPs).

input: Can private and public cloud peering types be configured simultaneously?
output: Yes, private and public cloud peering types can be configured simultaneously, but MCR does not exchange routes between the two.

output: VXCs support different types of peers based on the peering type defined for the VXC.

input: What routes are advertised by the private cloud peering type?

input: What peering options are available for private cloud connectivity?
output: For private cloud connectivity, peering options include AWS Direct Connect (Private VIF, Transit VIF), Azure ExpressRoute (Private Peering), Google Cloud Interconnect (Partner Interconnect Attachment), Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (FastConnect Private Peering), and others.

input: What peering options are available for public cloud connectivity?
output: For public cloud connectivity, peering options include AWS Direct Connect (Public VIF), Azure ExpressRoute (Microsoft Peering), Salesforce (ExpressConnect), Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (FastConnect Public Peering), and others.

input: How does MCR handle route advertisement scenarios involving non-cloud and private cloud connectivity?
output: MCR allows multi-tenant networks to exchange private RFC 1918 address space between non-cloud and private cloud environments through network virtualization and segmentation mechanisms.

input: What does the public cloud connectivity option require in terms of address space exchange?
output: The public cloud connectivity option requires the exchange of public address space, similar to peering with an internet service provider (ISP).

input: How does MCR prevent misconfiguration and global service disruption when peering with multiple public cloud providers?
output: MCR has default policies that prevent the inadvertent advertisement of public routes belonging to one cloud service provider to another, avoiding service disruptions. Routing mechanisms are also in place to restrict public cloud peering types from exchanging public address spaces.

input: What are the supported MCR route advertisement configuration types?
output: The supported MCR route advertisement configuration types are public cloud to non-cloud, private cloud to non-cloud and private cloud, and non-cloud to non-cloud, private cloud, and public cloud.

input: What is the purpose of the Megaport Cloud Router?
output: The Megaport Cloud Router (MCR) works in multi-cloud architectures, connecting different combinations of peering types and allowing connectivity with various cloud service providers (CSPs).

input: What is a VXC in the context of MCR?
output: A VXC in the context of MCR refers to a Virtual Cross Connect that connects MCR to other endpoints on the Megaport network.

input: Which Megaport peering attribute is associated with the non-cloud peering type?

input: What are the three parts to adding an ExpressRoute connection to MVE and vManage?

input: Where can I create the ExpressRoute connection in the Megaport Portal?

input: What information do I need to provide when creating the ExpressRoute connection in the Megaport Portal?

input: Can I deploy multiple connections with the same ExpressRoute service key?

input: What are the required details for configuring peerings in the Azure Resource Management console?

input: What are the steps to create a dedicated device template for the MVE in vManage?

input: What is the purpose of the Cisco VPN feature template in vManage?

input: What are the steps to create a BGP feature template for the connection peering details?

input: What is the purpose of the CLI Add-On feature template in vManage?
output: The CLI Add-On feature template in vManage is used to configure the sub-interface for the MVE. It includes the interface configuration, encapsulation settings, VRF forwarding, IP address assignment, and MTU value.

input: How do I add the feature templates to the device template in vManage?
output: To add the feature templates to the device template in vManage, you need to select the VPN template created in the Cisco VPN feature template, select the BGP template created in the Cisco BGP feature template, and select the CLI Add-On template created in the CLI Add-On feature template.

input: What is packet loss?
output: Packet loss is the failure of one or more packets to reach their intended destination in a network, resulting in disruptions or slow service.

input: How can I troubleshoot packet loss on a Port or VXC?
output: To troubleshoot packet loss on a Port or VXC, you can check for interface or CRC errors, verify Tx and Rx optical levels, validate physical connections, verify carrier circuit status, and validate equipment performance.

input: How can I check interface or CRC errors on a device?
output: You can check interface statistics and logs on a device to identify which end of the cross connect is causing the fault and find a potential solution.

input: What should I do if I observe degradation of Tx and Rx light levels?
output: If you observe degradation of Tx and Rx light levels, you should check your physical connections, including verifying fiber polarity, checking for connectivity issues within your environment or cross connect, or checking for connectivity issues within the Megaport environment.

input: What tests should I perform to verify physical connections with the data center?
output: You should reseat and replace SFPs, clean and replace cables, and perform loopback tests. Additionally, you can open a ticket with the data center to check the cross connect for damages or cleaning and ensure adequate light transmission at the demarcation point.

input: What should I verify about the carrier circuit status?
output: You should verify that the device interfaces in the cross connect path are free of errors and that optic light readings are operating correctly.

input: What equipment performance should I validate?
output: To validate equipment performance, you should ensure that the hardware specifications and limitations are compatible with Megaport Technical Specifications, monitor network traffic and workload to avoid congestion or degraded performance, and validate the performance of various hardware and network components.

input: How can traceroute help locate the symptom?
output: Traceroute is a network diagnostic tool that tracks the pathway taken by a packet from source to destination, reporting the IP addresses of all the routers along the path. Analyzing traceroute results can help identify potential asymmetric routing or delays within the network.

input: What should I do if the troubleshooting actions don't resolve the issue?
output: If the troubleshooting actions don't resolve the issue, you should contact support and provide them with detailed troubleshooting results, source and destination IP addresses, a high-level network diagram, ping test results, and traceroute results.

input: What information should I provide when contacting support?
output: When contacting support, you should provide detailed troubleshooting results, source and destination IP addresses, a high-level network diagram, ping test results, and traceroute results.

input: What should I do if a field service technician is needed onsite at the data center?
output: If a field service technician is needed onsite at the data center, you should refer to the Customer Field Services for further details and assistance.

input: How can I verify the status of a Port or VXC?
output: You can verify the status of a Port or VXC from the Megaport Portal by accessing the Services page and checking the icon color and the status message displayed when hovering over the service.

input: What is an SFP?
output: SFP stands for Small Form Pluggable, which is a hot pluggable transceiver used in data communication and telecommunication networks to enable data transmission between two devices.

input: What is a CRC error?
output: CRC stands for Cyclic Redundancy Check, which is a type of error detection code used to detect transmission errors in data. Increasing CRC errors on a network interface can indicate potential issues with other components of the cross connect.

input: How can I validate the physical connectivity of the Tx and Rx light?
output: You can check the transmitted (Tx) and received (Rx) light levels to validate physical connectivity. If no Rx light is received, the service is down. If you observe degradation of Tx and Rx light levels, it may indicate interruptions in the service.

input: What should I do if I'm not transmitting or receiving light to/from Megaport?
output: If you're not transmitting or receiving light to/from Megaport, it may be caused by a fiber polarity issue, connectivity issues within your environment or cross connect, or connectivity issues within the Megaport environment. You should verify and troubleshoot these potential causes.

input: What is a demarcation point?
output: A demarcation point is the physical point in a network where the responsibility for infrastructure changes from the service provider to the customer. Checking the light reading at the demarcation point can help identify issues with the connection.

input: What is an optic in the context of network equipment?
output: In the context of network equipment, an optic refers to an Optical Small Form-Factor Pluggable (SFP) module that provides optical connectivity for transmitting and receiving data over fiber optic cables.

input: What is an asymmetric routing?
output: Asymmetric routing refers to the situation when data packets take different paths in the network for traffic going from source to destination and from destination back to the source. This can cause potential issues and should be investigated if observed in traceroute results.

input: What are the benefits of direct connectivity to 3DS Outscale Connect through Megaport?

input: How does the connection to 3DS Outscale work?

input: Can I use a 31-bit subnet mask address for BGP peering with a Cloud Service Provider?
output: The answer depends on whether your on-premise device and the Cloud Service Provider support a configuration with a 31-bit subnet mask.

input: Does my on-premise device need to support a 31-bit subnet mask for BGP peering?
output: If you want to establish a BGP peering session with a Cloud Service Provider using a 31-bit subnet mask, your on-premise device needs to support this configuration.

input: Which Cloud Service Providers support a 31-bit subnet mask for BGP peering?
output: The majority of Cloud Service Providers, including AWS, Oracle, Alibaba, and IBM, support the use of a 31-bit subnet mask for BGP peering. However, Microsoft Azure ExpressRoute and Google Partner Interconnect do not currently support it.

input: What is the on-premise device warning when using a 31-bit subnet mask?
output: The warning that may be displayed by some older versions of network device operating systems is: '% Warning: use /31 mask on non point-to-point interface cautiously.'

input: How does Oracle Cloud Infrastructure FastConnect handle subnet mask selection?
output: For a private virtual circuit, you can specify a /30 or /31 network of your choice, and those IP addresses are assigned to the virtual circuit during the provisioning process. The IP addresses are used for BGP peer establishment. For a public virtual circuit, Oracle Cloud Infrastructure chooses the BGP IP addresses.

input: What subnet mask does IBM Direct Link assign for each connection?
output: IBM Cloud assigns a /31 or /30 for each connection and configures an interface IP address on the IBM Cloud cross-connect router (XCR) infrastructure.

input: What kind of CIDR does AWS Direct Connect provide for a private IPv4 VIF?
output: For a private IPv4 VIF, Amazon will provide you a /31 CIDR. However, note that you can use a /31 public CIDR for a Public IPv4 VIF.

input: What subnet masks are allowed for Alibaba Cloud Express Connect?
output: Alibaba Cloud Express Connect allows the use of a /30 or /31 subnet mask.

input: Does Microsoft Azure ExpressRoute support a 31-bit subnet mask?
output: No, Microsoft Azure ExpressRoute does not support nor have plans to support a 31-bit subnet mask.

input: Does Google Partner Interconnect currently support a 31-bit subnet mask?
output: No, Google Partner Interconnect does not currently support the use of a 31-bit subnet mask. The mask is fixed and assigned from a 169.254.0.0/16 pool.

input: When was the RFC 3021 released?
output: RFC 3021, which investigates the use of 31-bit prefixes on IPv4 point-to-point links, was released in December 2000.

input: Why was RFC 3021 developed?
output: RFC 3021 was developed to address the need for preserving IP address space and reducing the amount of IP addresses assigned to point-to-point links by allowing the use of 31-bit subnet masks. This was seen as a more efficient practice for point-to-point links where only two possible identifying hosts exist.

input: What is the standard practice for BGP peering with a Cloud Service Provider?
output: Currently, the standard practice for BGP peering with a Cloud Service Provider involves using a 30-bit subnet mask.

input: Why do organizations want to use a 31-bit subnet mask for BGP peering with Cloud Service Providers?
output: Due to the ongoing IP shortage and limited IP address space, organizations want to use a 31-bit subnet mask to optimize IP address allocation when establishing a BGP peering session with Cloud Service Providers.

input: How many addresses are available with a 31-bit subnet mask?
output: With a 31-bit subnet mask, there are only two possible addresses: a network address and a broadcast address, which in the case of a point-to-point link, must be interpreted as host addresses.

input: Does Megaport Cloud Router support a 31-bit subnet mask?
output: Yes, Megaport Cloud Router supports the use of 31-bit subnet masks on VXCs connected to customer devices, as well as on CSP-facing VXCs where the CSP supports this mask length.

input: Is there support for 31-bit subnet masks in Microsoft Azure ExpressRoute?
output: Unfortunately, Microsoft Azure ExpressRoute does not provide support for 31-bit subnet masks and currently has no plans of introducing it in the future.

input: What subnet mask does AWS Direct Connect offer for private VIFs and public VIFs?
output: For a private IPv4 VIF, Amazon provides a /31 CIDR. However, a /31 public CIDR can be used for a Public IPv4 VIF.

input: Can a 31-bit subnet mask be used with Google Partner Interconnect?
output: No, Google Partner Interconnect does not currently support the use of 31-bit subnet masks. The subnet mask is fixed and assigned from a 169.254.0.0/16 pool.

input: What is the recommendation for using a 31-bit subnet mask on non point-to-point interfaces?
output: The warning displayed by some older versions of network device operating systems is: '% Warning: use /31 mask on non point-to-point interface cautiously.' This warns users to be cautious when using a 31-bit subnet mask on non point-to-point interfaces.

input: What is a Link Aggregation Group?
output: A Link Aggregation Group (LAG) bundles physical ports to create a single data path, increasing overall connection reliability by distributing traffic load among the ports.

input: What are some other terms used to describe a LAG?
output: Other terms used to describe a LAG include port trunking, link bundling, and channel bonding.

input: When should you enable LACP for a new Port?
output: When you order a new Port that is 10 Gbps or higher, enabling the Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP) allows you to use it in a LAG. It is recommended to enable LACP even if you only require a single Port at that time.

input: How many physical Ports can be combined into a single LAG?
output: You can combine up to 8 physical Ports into a single LAG.

input: What are the benefits of using LAGs?
output: LAGs provide aggregate bandwidth, enhanced resiliency, and efficient use of resources by bundling physical ports into a single data path.

input: What does a LAG configuration with multiple physical cross-connects help in reducing?
output: A LAG configuration with multiple physical cross-connects helps reduce potential single points of failure that could disrupt the network.

input: What protocol is used for LACP?
output: LACP (Link Aggregation Control Protocol) follows the IEEE 802.1AX or previous IEEE 802.3ad standards.

input: What is the maximum number of interfaces supported in a single LAG?
output: A single LAG supports a maximum of 8 interfaces.

input: What are the bandwidth limitations of a LAG?
output: The available total bandwidth of a LAG is the sum of all the Ports in the LAG. However, Virtual Cross Connect (VXC) bandwidth is still limited to the maximum bandwidth of any single Port in the LAG.

input: What must be set to enable LACP functionality correctly?
output: The LACP System Priority must be set to a value higher than 0 on your equipment for LACP to function correctly.

input: What is the speed requirement for LAGs?
output: LAGs require a speed of 10 Gbps or higher. 1 Gbps Ports are not supported in LAGs.

input: Is Multi-Chassis Link Aggregation (MC-LAG) supported across multiple devices?
output: No, Multi-Chassis Link Aggregation (MC-LAG) is not supported across multiple devices.

input: What is recommended even if you only require a single Port at the time of ordering?
output: Enabling LACP is recommended even if you only require a single Port at the time of ordering to prevent service interruption if you decide to enable LACP on the Port later.

input: What is the maximum term you can specify when creating a Port?
output: You can specify a minimum term of 1 month, 12 months, or 36 months when creating a Port.

input: What are the options for Port Diversity when creating a new LAG?
output: When creating a new LAG, you can select None, Create Diverse Pair, or Diverse from Existing Port for Port Diversity options.

input: How many LAGs can be created when selecting the Create Diverse Pair option?
output: When selecting the Create Diverse Pair option, two LAGs are created, each in its own diversity zone.

input: How many Ports can be included in a LAG?
output: You can include up to a maximum of 8 Ports in a LAG.

input: What is the process to convert a non-LAG Port to a LAG?
output: To convert a non-LAG Port to a LAG, send a request to Megaport Support to manually convert the Port. Make sure to identify the Port in your request.

input: What should be provided to the data center operator to establish the physical cross connect?
output: Provide the Letter of Authorization (LOA) to your data center operator to establish the physical cross connect from your network device to your new Port.

input: How many LAGs can be created from a non-LAG Port?
output: A non-LAG Port can be converted to a LAG, resulting in the creation of a single LAG.

input: What is the purpose of creating a Virtual Cross Connect (VXC)?
output: The purpose of creating a VXC is to establish a private point-to-point Ethernet connection between an A-End and a B-End without the need for physical infrastructure.

input: How is a VXC mapped?
output: A VXC is mapped with a VLAN ID on each end.

input: What are the two main types of IX peering arrangements?

input: What is multilateral peering?

input: What is bilateral peering?

input: What are the features of VM-Series?

input: What SASE elements does VM-Series extend between the edge and cloud network fabric?

output: A VLAN tag for a VXC connection is a 802.1q VLAN identifier that is used to differentiate the connection within a Port. Each VXC is delivered as a separate VLAN on your Port, and you can specify a unique VLAN ID for the A-End and B-End of the connection.

input: Can I deliver a VXC connection as an untagged VLAN?
output: Yes, you can choose to deliver a VXC connection as an untagged VLAN. However, this consumes the entire Port and prevents any other VXCs from being deployed on the same Port.

input: How can I view the VXCs I have deployed in the Megaport Portal?
output: To view the VXCs you have deployed in the Megaport Portal, go to the Services page. There, you will be able to see the list of VXCs along with their respective details.

input: What is a service level reference for a VXC?
output: A service level reference for a VXC is a unique identifying number that you can specify for billing purposes. It can be used as a cost center number or a unique customer ID. The service level reference number will appear for each service in the invoice.

input: What is the diversity zone for an A-End service in Megaport?
output: The diversity zone for an A-End service in Megaport refers to the geographical zone or area where the service is deployed and available. It is visible after the service is deployed and can help prevent accidentally crossing zones when ordering diverse Ports.

input: Can I create multiple VXCs with diverse Ports?
output: Yes, you can create multiple VXCs with diverse Ports. When ordering multiple VXCs and diverse Ports, the Port diversity zone will be visible before deploying to ensure they are set up correctly and prevent accidental zone crossings.

input: What should I do if the location does not support diversity in Megaport?
output: If the location does not support diversity in Megaport, you will not see the diversity zone for the Port. In such cases, you can proceed with the VXC creation without considering the diversity zone.

input: Can partner managed accounts apply a Partner Deal to a VXC?
output: Yes, partner managed accounts can apply a Partner Deal to a VXC. This allows them to associate a partner deal with the service. For more information, refer to the documentation on associating a deal with a service.

input: What is the purpose of connecting a production data center to a redundant data center using a private VXC?
output: Connecting a production data center to a redundant data center using a private VXC allows for establishing a disaster recovery setup. In the event of failure or downtime at the production data center, the private VXC ensures seamless failover to the redundant data center, minimizing service disruptions.

input: What happens if I specify a VLAN ID that is already in use for a VXC connection?
output: If you specify a VLAN ID that is already in use for a VXC connection, the system will display the next available VLAN number. Each VLAN ID must be unique within a Port to proceed with the order.

input: What is the range of VLAN IDs I can specify for a VXC connection?
output: For a VXC connection, you can specify a VLAN ID ranging from 2 to 4093. The VLAN ID must be unique within the Port where the VXC is deployed.

input: Is there a limit on the number of VXCs I can create on a Port?
output: There is no specific limit on the number of VXCs you can create on a Port. However, the available capacity of the Port and any rate limits set for the VXCs will determine the number of concurrent connections you can establish.

input: Can I edit the service level reference number for an existing VXC?
output: Yes, you can edit the service level reference number for an existing VXC. Simply locate the VXC in the Megaport Portal and modify the service level reference as needed.

input: How can I delete a private VXC in Megaport?
output: To delete a private VXC in Megaport, go to the Services page in the Megaport Portal. Locate the VXC you want to delete and use the appropriate action or delete option provided.

input: What is Megaport Cloud Router (MCR) and how does it relate to private VXCs?
output: Megaport Cloud Router (MCR) is a virtual routing service offered by Megaport. It allows you to create virtual routers in the cloud and connect them to private VXCs. You can refer to the documentation on creating a VXC for Megaport Cloud Router to learn more about utilizing MCR with private VXCs.

input: Can I use the same VLAN tag for the A-End and B-End of a VXC connection?
output: No, you cannot use the same VLAN tag for the A-End and B-End of a VXC connection. Each end must have a unique VLAN tag to ensure proper differentiation and communication within the Port.

input: What is Network Address Translation (NAT)?
output: Network Address Translation (NAT) is a technique used to conserve IPv4 address space by translating private IP addresses used in an organization's private network into a single registered public IP address.

input: How does NAT work on the MCR?
output: NAT on the MCR translates private IP addresses to a single, globally unique public IP address. It uses many-to-one translation, allowing multiple private source IP addresses to be hidden behind the MCR's IP address.

input: What is the purpose of NAT in connecting to Cloud Service Providers?
output: NAT on the MCR is designed to support public peering types to Cloud Service Providers. It allows private IP addresses to be translated to public addresses so that organizations can connect to Cloud Service Providers using public IPv4 addresses.

input: What is the difference between SNAT and PAT in MCR NAT?
output: MCR NAT uses a combination of source NAT (SNAT) and port address translation (PAT) to map multiple private IP addresses to a single public IP address. SNAT translates the source IP address, while PAT assigns unique TCP or UDP source ports.

input: How does MCR keep track of IP address translations and port assignments?
output: MCR maintains a NAT table that can handle thousands of concurrent translations. It keeps track of each IP address translation and port assignment, releasing unused ports back to the pool.

input: How does MCR NAT support connectivity to Cloud Service Providers' public services?
output: MCR NAT overload, also known as many-to-one NAT, allows organizations to connect to Cloud Service Providers' public services by translating private IP addresses to a single public IP address.

input: What is the benefit of using MCR for connectivity to Cloud Service Providers?
output: MCR provides the added benefit of using Megaport's autonomous system number (ASN) and publicly registered IP space for the connection to Cloud Service Providers.

input: What is the function of the NAT IP Address field in MCR?
output: The NAT IP Address field in MCR represents the IP address of the MCR's outside interface, to which packets will be translated.

input: What are the supported MCR NAT configurations and use cases?
output: Supported MCR NAT configurations include NAT overload, hide NAT, and destination NAT for connectivity to various services. Source NAT, static NAT pool, and dynamic NAT pool are not suitable for MCR NAT use cases.

input: What is the purpose of NAT Overload in MCR NAT?
output: NAT Overload in MCR NAT allows organizations to establish connectivity to Cloud Service Providers' public services by translating multiple private IP addresses to a single public IP address.

input: When is Hide NAT used in MCR NAT?
output: Hide NAT in MCR NAT is used to establish connectivity to Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) and Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) services, enabling the translation of private IP addresses to public addresses.

input: What is the use case for Source NAT in MCR NAT?
output: Source NAT is not suitable for MCR NAT use cases, specifically for connectivity to Megaport Marketplace partners.

input: What is the use case for Destination NAT in MCR NAT?
output: Destination NAT is not suitable for MCR NAT use cases when the goal is to preserve the IP address space for outbound traffic.

input: When is a Static NAT Pool configuration not appropriate in MCR NAT?
output: A Static NAT Pool configuration is not suitable for MCR NAT when the requirement is to allow for inbound access from the internet.

input: When is a Dynamic NAT Pool configuration not recommended in MCR NAT?
output: A Dynamic NAT Pool configuration is not recommended for MCR NAT when the goal is routing between overlapping networks.

input: How is MCR connected to Azure using NAT?
output: MCR is connected to Azure using a Virtual Cross Connect (VXC) for both private and public Microsoft peering types. NAT is used to translate private IP addresses to public addresses for connectivity to Azure.

input: What VLAN IDs are used for private and public peering in MCR?
output: MCR automatically configures VLAN 100 for private peering and VLAN 200 for the public Microsoft peering. These VLANs are used when provisioning VXCs from the MCR to a service provider.

input: Does MCR support 802.1Q tunnel for multiple Azure VXCs?
output: Yes, MCR manages the 802.1Q tunnel, also known as a Q-in-Q tunnel, for each Azure VXC that terminates on the MCR. Each Azure VLAN is treated as a separate logical interface.

input: How does MCR NAT handle packets between a customer's data center and Azure?
output: When a packet is sent from the customer's data center to Azure via MCR, MCR performs source NAT (SNAT) and port address translation (PAT) to translate the private source IP address to a public IP address.

input: How does MCR NAT ensure unique sessions for translated packets?
output: MCR assigns a different TCP or UDP source port number to each session, ensuring uniqueness and enabling proper communication between the MCR and the destination.

output: No, Megaport Support cannot reset or regenerate QR codes for customers. A Company Admin must perform this task in the Megaport Portal.

input: Can you disable MFA for your account?
output: If MFA is set to optional globally for your company and you are currently using MFA, you can disable MFA by choosing User Profile under your username on the dashboard and clicking Disable MFA. Then, click Disable Multi-factor Authentication.

input: What are the benefits of using MFA?
output: Using Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) adds an extra layer of security to your Megaport Portal account by requiring multiple verification factors for login, enhancing identity and access management (IAM) policy.

input: Which app is recommended for MFA?

input: What information is displayed on the User Profile page?

input: What should you do if your password is rejected even after meeting all complexity requirements?
output: If your password is rejected even after meeting all complexity requirements, the likely cause is that the password is too common or easy to guess. Try using a less common password or include additional complexity.

input: What happens after enabling MFA?
output: After enabling Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA), you need to supply a valid token from the authenticator app every time you log in to the Megaport Portal, in addition to your email and password.

input: What happens after disabling MFA?
output: After disabling Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA), you will no longer be prompted for a valid token from the authenticator app when logging in to the Megaport Portal.

input: Can a Company Admin reset MFA for your account?

input: What are some troubleshooting steps to confirm if the BGP session is the root cause of IX issues?
output: You can check interface or CRC errors and packet drops on the device, verify interface, SFP, cable and cabling are correct, verify Layer 2 and Layer 3 configurations, check optic power levels on the device, perform ping tests to route servers and bilateral peers, and verify the BGP configuration.

input: How can I check interface or CRC errors and packet drops on the device?
output: You can view interface statistics and logs to identify which end of the cross connect is causing the fault and potential solutions. Increasing number of incoming errors on a network interface may indicate potential issues with other components of the IX.

input: What should I verify regarding interface, SFP, cable, and cabling?
output: You should verify that the auto-negotiation (speed auto and duplex auto) is used on gigabit interfaces, the cross connect cable is connected to the correct port at both ends, and the SFP optic power levels (Tx and Rx) show good light at both ends.

input: What Layer 2 configurations should I verify?
output: You should verify that the MTU size is correct, the LACP configuration is correct if LAG is used, and your devices are configured as per the 'Preferred A-End VLAN' on the Megaport Portal. Additionally, if a VLAN is used, confirm if the correct VLAN number is configured on your device side.

input: What Layer 3 configurations should I verify?
output: You should verify that the interface IP address and subnet address are configured correctly, and the routing protocol configurations (EIGRP/OSPF/BGP) are configured correctly. You can also run ping tests between Layer 3 network devices and between source and destination hosts to check for end-to-end connectivity.

input: How can I verify the optic power levels on the device?
output: You can check the optic light readings from the terminal and ensure that the readings are within the threshold range. You can also view the device and port graphs for errors and refer to the Megaport optic graphs history.

input: What is the purpose of performing a ping test to route servers and bilateral peers?
output: A ping test helps to confirm or deny the connectivity between IP-networked devices. It also provides information about the latency (response time) of the connection to the route servers and bilateral peers.

input: How can I verify Layer 2 connectivity to route servers and bilateral peers?
output: You can check the Layer 2 connectivity by confirming that the MAC address is visible in the Megaport Portal and that the correct VLAN configuration details are used. It's important to ensure the accuracy of VLAN configurations, especially when connecting to Azure using Q-in-Q.

input: What should I provide when contacting support for further assistance?
output: When requesting assistance, provide detailed information about the troubleshooting steps you have taken, excerpts of network device configurations, interface configurations, static routes and routing protocol configurations, firewall rules and ACL configurations, BGP command output, routing table at both ends, traceroute logs, and packet capture logs if possible.

input: How can I check for BGP error messages?
output: You can check for BGP error messages by examining the BGP protocol notification messages. These messages are sent when an error is detected, such as an expiring hold timer or a change to neighbor capabilities. In case of an error, the BGP session is closed.

input: What are the next steps if the troubleshooting actions do not resolve the issue?
output: If the troubleshooting actions do not resolve the issue, you should contact support. When contacting support, provide all the troubleshooting steps you have taken in detail, as well as relevant network device configurations, routing tables, BGP command output, and any other pertinent information.

input: What should I do if a field service technician is needed onsite at the data center?
output: In case a field service technician is needed onsite at the data center, refer to the 'Customer Field Services' for detailed instructions and assistance.

input: What is the purpose of the MegaIX Looking Glass tool provided by Megaport?
output: The MegaIX Looking Glass tool allows peers and network operators to investigate the current routing state. It provides access to both the primary and redundant route servers for live BGP data, enabling queries and analysis of the routing information.

input: What is the maximum number of interfaces allowed in a single LAG?
output: The maximum number of interfaces allowed in a single LAG is 8. It's important to note that multi-chassis link aggregation (MC-LAG) across multiple devices is not supported.

input: What is the purpose of Q-in-Q (IEEE 802.1ad) in the context of Azure VXC?
output: Q-in-Q (IEEE 802.1ad) is a technique used by OSI Layer 2 providers, including Azure VXC. It provides for both an inner and an outer tag, allowing the segmentation of data. Depending on the method chosen, device configurations can vary, including Q-in-Q, Q-in-Q breakout, untagged VXC, or MCR.

input: What should I confirm if I am peering with Megaport or other organizations using IX services?
output: If you are peering with Megaport or other organizations using IX services, you should confirm that the MAC address specified in the Megaport Portal is correct. Additionally, you can check the status of your IX service using the Looking Glass tool and provide Megaport with Layer 2 connectivity details for further assistance.

input: What can cause Layer 2 connectivity issues that impact IX services?
output: Layer 2 connectivity issues can be caused by incorrect VLAN configuration details, authentication issues with MAC addresses, or incorrect configurations when connecting to Cloud Service Providers (CSPs) like Azure. It's important to ensure the accuracy of Layer 2 configurations to maintain the functionality of your VXCs and IX services.

input: What should I verify regarding the BGP configuration?
output: When verifying the BGP configuration, you should check the interface settings, including the VLAN number, BGP IP address and subnet mask, BGP AS number, BGP network addresses to be advertised and received, BGP neighbor IP address and subnet mask, BGP neighbor AS number, BGP authentication, and any route filtering and manipulation settings.

input: What information should I provide when contacting support for IX troubleshooting?
output: When contacting support for IX troubleshooting, it's helpful to provide information about the troubleshooting steps taken, network device configurations, interface configurations, routing protocol information, BGP command output, routing table at both ends, traceroute logs, and packet capture logs if available.

input: How can I collect traceroute logs between the source and destination host?
output: To collect traceroute logs between the source and destination host, you can run the 'traceroute' command on your network devices or use traceroute tools available in various operating systems. The logs will show the path traversed by the packets and help identify any network connectivity issues.

input: What should I do if the troubleshooting actions do not resolve the issue with IX?
output: If the troubleshooting actions do not resolve the issue with IX, you should contact support for further assistance. Provide detailed information about the troubleshooting steps taken, network device configurations, routing tables, BGP command output, and any relevant logs to help diagnose and resolve the problem.

input: What is the purpose of connecting Megaport Virtual Edge (MVE) integrated with Versa Secure SD-WAN to another MVE?
output: The purpose is to create a private point-to-point Ethernet connection between branch locations using the Megaport private software-defined network (SDN) and reduce reliance on the internet.

input: How can I connect two MVEs on the Megaport network?
output: You can create a private VXC (Virtual Cross Connect) between the A-End and B-End MVEs in the Megaport Portal. This establishes a private point-to-point Ethernet connection between the two MVEs without the need for physical infrastructure.

input: Can MVEs exchange traffic over the internet?
output: Yes, the internet-facing interface on an MVE can reach the internet-facing interface on another MVE over the public internet. This allows for traffic exchange between MVEs in different metros.

input: What are the prerequisites for creating a VXC between two MVEs?
output: You need to provision two MVEs in different locations and configure them in the Megaport Portal. Once the MVEs are created, you can proceed to create a VXC between them.

input: How do I create a VXC in the Megaport Portal?
output: To create a VXC, go to the Services page in the Megaport Portal, click + Connection next to the A-End MVE, select Private VXC, and follow the prompts to specify the B-End MVE, IP addressing, VLANs, and optional BGP parameters.

input: What information do I need to specify when creating a VXC?
output: You need to specify a connection name, service level reference (optional), rate limit, A-End and B-End vNICs, and VLAN tag for the connection. Consult Aruba's documentation for details on rate limits and vNIC selection.

input: How can I view the deployed VXCs in the Megaport Portal?
output: You can view the deployed VXCs in the Services page of the Megaport Portal. The VXCs will be listed under the A-End and B-End MVEs.

input: What are the next steps after creating the VXC between two MVEs?
output: The next step is to configure the A-End and B-End MVEs in Versa Director. This involves configuring subinterfaces, IP addresses, next hops, and BGP settings for each MVE.

input: How do I configure the A-End MVE in Versa Director?
output: To configure the A-End MVE, collect the connection details from the Megaport Portal, log in to Versa Director, select the appropriate template, and configure subinterfaces, IP addresses, BGP settings, and other relevant parameters.

input: What values do I need to specify when configuring the A-End MVE in Versa Director?
output: You need to specify the VLAN ID, network name, IPv4 settings, local AS, neighbor IP address, peer AS, and optionally enable BFD. These values depend on your MVE configuration and network design.

input: How can I parameterize certain fields in the Versa Director template?
output: To parameterize fields like Router ID, BGP Local AS, Peer AS, and Password, go to the Device Templates section in Versa Director, select your template, and click the Parameterize icon next to each field. Then, specify values for the variables in the Bind Data tab.

input: What steps are involved in configuring the B-End MVE in Versa Director?
output: To configure the B-End MVE, you need to follow similar steps as configuring the A-End MVE. Collect the connection details, select the appropriate template, configure subinterfaces, IP addresses, BGP settings, and other relevant parameters.

input: Can I use the same template for both A-End and B-End MVEs?
output: Yes, you can use the same template for both A-End and B-End MVEs if they are in the same device group and share the same template. You can then make changes to the variables in the Bind Data for the B-End device to configure the connection.

input: How can I verify the connection after configuring the MVEs?
output: To verify the connection, go to the Monitor tab in Versa Director, select your device, and review the subinterface in the Interface column. You can also check the Operational and Admin Status to ensure the connection is active.

input: What is the purpose of creating a private VXC between MVEs integrated with Versa Secure SD-WAN?
output: The purpose is to establish a secure and private point-to-point Ethernet connection between enterprise branch locations using the Megaport private software-defined network (SDN), reducing reliance on the public internet.

input: Can MVEs communicate with each other across different metros?
output: Yes, MVEs can exchange traffic over the public internet, allowing them to communicate with each other across different metros. The connectivity is customer/SD-WAN partner managed and not Megaport managed.

input: How can I integrate Megaport with SAP on AWS?
output: You can use Megaport to create a Direct Connect Layer 2 connection between your on-premises or colocation-based infrastructure and your SAP environment on AWS.

input: What is required before integrating Megaport with SAP on AWS?
output: Before integrating Megaport with SAP on AWS, you need to create a Megaport connection or Port.

input: How can I create a Megaport connection or Port?
output: You can create a Megaport connection or Port in one of their global data centers/Points of Presence (PoPs). If your company isn't located in one of their PoPs, you can procure a last mile circuit to one of the sites to connect to Megaport.

input: What is a Virtual Cross Connect (VXC)?
output: A Virtual Cross Connect (VXC) is a point-to-point Ethernet connection between your Megaport Port (A-End) and your SAP instance on AWS (B-End).

input: How can I add an AWS connection for my Megaport Port?
output: In the Megaport Portal, go to the Services page, select the Port you want to use, and add an AWS connection. You can choose either Hosted VIF or Hosted Connection as the AWS Connection Type.

input: What is the purpose of the Preferred A-End VLAN?
output: The Preferred A-End VLAN is an optional field where you can specify an unused VLAN ID for the connection. It must be unique to the Port and can range from 2 to 4093. If not specified, Megaport will assign one.

input: How can I specify the cloud details for the Megaport-AWS connection?
output: You need to specify the Type (Public or Private) and enter the AWS Connection Name, AWS Account ID, Customer ASN, BGP Auth Key (optional), Customer IP Address, and Amazon IP Address (optional).

input: How can I connect the new VXC to the SAP on AWS instance?
output: After placing the order, log in to your AWS account and accept the Virtual Interface (VIF) in the Direct Connect section. Attach the VIF to either a Virtual Gateway (VGW) or a Direct Connect Gateway (DGW) based on your solution's design.

input: How can I achieve redundancy for the Megaport-AWS connectivity?
output: To achieve redundancy, you can establish additional VXCs to the AWS environment. For physical redundancy, you can implement the VXCs on separate Ports.

input: What is the hybrid model of operating SAP on AWS?
output: In the hybrid model, SAP on AWS can be operated with on-premises (global) and cloud resources working together. A Direct Connect Layer 2 connection enabled through Megaport connects the on-premise infrastructure to the AWS cloud.

input: Where can I find technical documentation for SAP on AWS?

input: How can I migrate SAP solutions to AWS?

input: What resources can the VPC connect to in the AWS cloud?
output: The VPC can connect to a wide array of AWS resources in the AWS cloud.

input: What is the purpose of the Service Level Reference?
output: The Service Level Reference is an optional field where you can specify a unique identifying number for the VXC. This can be used for billing purposes, such as a cost center number or a unique customer ID.

input: What is the minimum and maximum rate limit for the connection speed?
output: The accepted values for the Rate Limit range from 1 Mbps to 5 Gbps in 1 Mbps increments.

input: Can the total sum of hosted virtual VXCs exceed the Port capacity?
output: Yes, the sum of all hosted virtual VXCs to a service can exceed the Port capacity, but the total aggregate will never burst beyond the Port capacity (1 or 10 Gbps).

input: What is the range of private ASN for Private Direct Connects?
output: The supported private ASN range for Private Direct Connects is 64512 - 65535.

input: What happens if I don't specify a VLAN ID for the connection?
output: If you don't specify a VLAN ID, Megaport will assign one for the connection.

input: What is the purpose of the BGP Auth Key?
output: The BGP Auth Key is an optional field where you can specify the BGP MD5 key. If left blank, Megaport negotiates a key automatically for you with AWS.

input: What information do I need to provide for the Megaport-AWS connection?
output: You need to provide the Type (Public or Private), AWS Connection Name, AWS Account ID, Customer ASN, BGP Auth Key (optional), Customer IP Address, and Amazon IP Address.

input: How do I create a Hosted Connection from an MVE to AWS?
output: To create a Hosted Connection from an MVE to AWS, go to the Megaport Portal, select the MVE for the connection, click +Connection, select Cloud, choose AWS as the service provider, select Hosted Connection as the AWS Connection Type, specify the connection details, and order the connection.

input: What types of connections can a Hosted Connection support?
output: A Hosted Connection can support one private, public, or transit virtual interface.

input: What should I do after deploying a VXC connection in the Megaport Portal?
output: After deploying a VXC connection in the Megaport Portal, you need to accept the connection in the AWS console and create a Virtual Interface for the connection.

input: How do I accept a Hosted Connection in the AWS console?
output: To accept a Hosted Connection in the AWS console, go to Services > AWS Direct Connect > Connections, click on the connection name, and click Accept.

input: What is the purpose of creating a Virtual Interface in AWS?
output: Creating a Virtual Interface in AWS allows you to connect your Hosted Connection to AWS services and resources.

input: How can I create a VIF and attach it to a Hosted Connection?
output: To create and attach a VIF to a Hosted Connection, go to the AWS console, click Create Virtual Interface, select the interface type (private, public, or transit), specify the configuration details, such as the virtual interface name and connection, and click Create virtual interface.

input: What information do I need to add a LAN interface in Aruba Orchestrator?
output: To add a LAN interface in Aruba Orchestrator, you need to collect the connection details from the AWS console and the Megaport Portal, such as the BGP ASN, BGP Auth Key, Your Peer IP, Amazon Peer IP, and A-End VLAN.

input: How do I configure BGP settings in Aruba Orchestrator?
output: To configure BGP settings in Aruba Orchestrator, go to Configuration > Networking | Routing | BGP, edit the appliance, enable BGP, provide the Autonomous System Number (ASN), specify the BGP Peers details, and apply the configuration.

input: How can I validate my AWS connection from the CLI?
output: To validate your AWS connection from the CLI, you can use commands like 'show interface wan0.<subinterface id>' to display configuration details and current status for the appliances, and 'show bgp neighbors' or 'show bgp summary' to display configuration details and current status for the BGP neighbors.

input: What do I need to do after configuring BGP settings in Aruba Orchestrator?
output: After configuring BGP settings in Aruba Orchestrator, you can check the BGP status for the VIF in the AWS console and verify the AWS BGP session is up.

input: How many connections can a Hosted Connection support?
output: A Hosted Connection can support one private, public, or transit virtual interface.

input: What is the purpose of specifying a Service Level Reference for a VXC?
output: Specifying a Service Level Reference for a VXC allows you to provide a unique identifying number for billing purposes, such as a cost center number or a unique customer ID.

input: Can I change the speed of a connection after it is deployed?
output: No, the speed of a connection cannot be changed once it is deployed.

input: What should I do if I don't specify a VLAN ID for a connection?
output: If you don't specify a VLAN ID for a connection, Megaport will assign one for you.

input: How can I add a LAN interface in Aruba Orchestrator?
output: To add a LAN interface in Aruba Orchestrator, go to Configuration > Networking | Routing | Deployment, locate the appliance, click the Edit icon, and add a new LAN interface or edit an existing one.

input: What is the purpose of configuring BGP settings in Aruba Orchestrator?
output: Configuring BGP settings in Aruba Orchestrator allows the appliance to establish and manage BGP sessions with AWS for the Hosted Connection.

input: What can I do if the BGP state appears as down in Aruba Orchestrator?
output: If the BGP state appears as down in Aruba Orchestrator, you should check the BGP configuration, verify the BGP settings, and ensure the BGP sessions are correctly established.

input: How can I start a CLI session from Aruba Orchestrator?
output: To start a CLI session from Aruba Orchestrator, hover over the appliance, click the Appliance Menu icon, and choose CLI Session. Then enter enable mode to use the CLI commands for displaying configuration details.

input: What information do I need to collect from the AWS console for configuring a Hosted Connection in Aruba Orchestrator?
output: For configuring a Hosted Connection in Aruba Orchestrator, you need to collect information such as the BGP ASN, BGP Auth Key, Your Peer IP, and Amazon Peer IP from the AWS console.

input: What is the purpose of Megaport in integrating with Azure VMware Solution?
output: Megaport is used to create an Azure ExpressRoute Layer 2 connection between on-premises or colocation-based infrastructure and the VMware environment on Azure.

input: How can you create a Megaport connection?
output: To create a Megaport connection, you need to create a Port and then connect a Virtual Cross Connect (VXC) from the Port to the virtual gateway associated with the Azure VNET infrastructure.

input: What services can CloudSimple provide in implementing VMware in Azure?
output: CloudSimple provides VMware-as-a-Service in public clouds, fully managed, validated, and supported by VMware. It allows you to implement a VMware solution using familiar tools and services including vSphere, vCenter, vSAN, and NSX.

input: How do you set up VMware within Azure using CloudSimple?
output: You can log in to your Azure account, search for VMware or CloudSimple, choose VMware Solution by CloudSimple - Service, and then specify the project details such as subscription, resource group, name, location, and gateway CIDR for the service.

input: What is the purpose of creating an authorization on the ExpressRoute circuit?
output: Creating an authorization on the ExpressRoute circuit allows you to use ExpressRoute for connectivity between your on-premise infrastructure and VMware on Azure. This authorization needs to be provided to CloudSimple.

input: How do you create an authorization on the ExpressRoute circuit?
output: To create an authorization on the ExpressRoute circuit, you can log in to the Azure console, search for ExpressRoute, choose or create a circuit to authorize, and then enter a name for the authorization. The authorization key and resource ID need to be copied and provided to CloudSimple.

input: What is the purpose of integration between Megaport and VMware Cloud on Azure?
output: The integration between Megaport and VMware Cloud on Azure allows you to create a virtual cross connect (VXC) from Megaport to the VMware Cloud on Azure environment, enabling seamless connectivity.

input: How do you set up the integration between Megaport and VMware Cloud on Azure?
output: After completing the ExpressRoute authorization process, you can use the Megaport Portal to create the VXC by providing the Microsoft Azure Service Key obtained from your Azure Console. You can specify connection details such as connection name, service level reference, rate limit, and A-End VLAN.

input: What options are available for achieving redundancy in the connectivity portion of the solution?
output: You can achieve redundancy by establishing additional VXCs to the Azure environment, and if implemented on separate Ports, additional physical redundancy can be achieved.

input: What is the benefit of using VMware Cloud for an enterprise?
output: VMware Cloud allows enterprises to take a slow and low-risk approach to cloud adoption by augmenting existing on-premises infrastructure with cloud resources for growth purposes. It also enables the utilization of existing equipment and infrastructure while preparing for an eventual full migration to the cloud.

input: Where can VMware on Azure be found?
output: VMware on Azure can be found in existing Azure VMware Regions by CloudSimple. More information can be found in the provided FAQ.

input: How can I create a Megaport connection if I'm not a Megaport customer?
output: If you're not a Megaport customer, you can create a 1 Gbps, 10 Gbps, or 100 Gbps Port in one of their global data centers/Points of Presence. If your company isn't located in one of their PoPs, you can procure a last mile circuit to one of the sites to connect to Megaport.

input: What are the familiar tools and services provided by CloudSimple for implementing VMware in Azure?
output: CloudSimple provides familiar tools and services including vSphere, vCenter, vSAN, and NSX for implementing VMware in Azure.

input: What should I do if I require a physically separate Port location for integrating Megaport with Azure VMware Solution?
output: If you require a physically separate Port location, it is recommended to create a new one before proceeding with the integration.

input: Can I use ExpressRoute to connect to a cloud-only instance of Azure VMware Solution?
output: Yes, ExpressRoute can be used to connect to a cloud-only instance of Azure VMware Solution.

input: Is CloudSimple managed and supported by VMware?
output: Yes, CloudSimple is fully managed, validated, and supported by VMware.

input: What are the requirements for using ExpressRoute for connectivity between on-premise infrastructure and VMware on Azure?
output: To use ExpressRoute for connectivity, you need to create an authorization on the ExpressRoute circuit and provide it to CloudSimple. Additionally, BGP needs to be used to connect the on-premises environment with the Azure infrastructure.

input: Can you create a virtual machine in Azure using CloudSimple?
output: Yes, CloudSimple allows you to create virtual machines in Azure as part of the implementation of VMware within the platform.

input: What IP subnet should be used for the gateway when creating VMware Solution by CloudSimple in Azure?
output: When creating VMware Solution by CloudSimple in Azure, a /28 IP subnet should be used for the gateway. This IP block should be unique and not overlap with any other IP block associated with the CloudSimple environment.

input: What protocols are used for delivering ExpressRoute services to Microsoft ports by Megaport?
output: Megaport delivers ExpressRoute services to Microsoft ports using Q-in-Q, allowing for seamless delivery of the inner tags (C-Tags) natively as 802.1Q VLANs.

input: What is VMware Cloud on AWS?
output: VMware Cloud on AWS is a service that allows you to spin up a VMware Software-Defined Data Center (SDDC) within the AWS cloud.

input: What are the benefits of using VMware Cloud on AWS?
output: Some benefits of VMware Cloud on AWS include the ability to take a slow and low-risk approach to cloud adoption, augmenting existing infrastructure with cloud resources, and avoiding new capital expenditures on equipment.

input: How is the VMware software implemented in AWS?
output: The VMware software is implemented directly on AWS bare metal, while support and management functions are performed by VMware and physical device management is handled by AWS.

input: Can I have root or SSH access to vSphere?
output: No, you do not have root or SSH access to vSphere in the VMware Cloud on AWS environment.

input: Can I install 3rd-party plugins in VMware Cloud on AWS?
output: No, you cannot install 3rd-party VIBs or plugins in the VMware Cloud on AWS environment.

input: How can I connect my on-premises infrastructure to VMware Cloud on AWS?
output: You can use Megaport as your Network-as-a-Service provider to deploy Virtual Interfaces (VIF) through AWS Direct Connect for connectivity between your on-premises infrastructure and VMware Cloud on AWS.

input: What is required for vMotion between a VMkernel source and destination?
output: For vMotion between a VMkernel source and destination, a minimum bandwidth of 250 Mbps is required with a maximum round trip latency of 150 ms.

input: Where is VMware Cloud on AWS currently available?
output: VMware Cloud on AWS is currently available in US East (N. Virginia), US East (Ohio), US West (N. California), US West (Oregon), Asia Pacific (Sydney), Asia Pacific (Tokyo), Europe (Frankfurt), Europe (Ireland), Europe (London), and AWS GovCloud (US). Additional regions are pending.

input: How can I achieve redundancy in the connectivity for VMware Cloud on AWS?
output: You can achieve redundancy by establishing additional VXCs to the AWS environment and implementing them on separate Ports. You can also establish an internet VPN for redundancy purposes.

input: Where can I find more information about VMware Cloud on AWS?
output: For more information about VMware Cloud on AWS, you can refer to the provided links and resources: VMware Cloud on AWS, VMware Cloud on AWS FAQ, AWS Overview of VMware Cloud on AWS, VMware Cloud on AWS - AWS News Blog, VMware Cloud Best Practice & Deep Dive Content, and Using AWS Direct Connect with VMware Cloud on AWS.

input: How can I get started with VMware Cloud on AWS?
output: To get started with VMware Cloud on AWS, you need to register for an account or sign in to your existing account on my.vmware.com. From there, you can create a new SDDC and provide the necessary information such as the AWS account, management network IPs, number of hosts, and AWS region.

input: What is the connectivity model used for VMware Cloud on AWS?
output: AWS uses AWS Direct Connect to simplify the connectivity model for VMware Cloud on AWS. Megaport can be used as a Network-as-a-Service provider to deploy Virtual Interfaces (VIF) through AWS Direct Connect.

input: How long does it take to spin up and provision the initial VMware Cloud on AWS environment?
output: The initial environment takes up to two hours to spin up and provision, while subsequent additions, deletions, and changes to hosts can happen in a matter of minutes.

input: Can I advertise my on-premises networks to the VMware Cloud SDDC?
output: Yes, you can advertise your on-premises networks to the VMware Cloud SDDC, allowing for simplified full connectivity and taking advantage of the bandwidth connections from Direct Connect.

input: How many logical network routes can be advertised from the VMware Cloud SDDC to on-premises?
output: The maximum number of logical network routes that can be advertised from the VMware Cloud SDDC to on-premises is 16, but this limit can be increased by VMware.

input: Can I establish redundancy for the connectivity portion of this solution?
output: Yes, you can achieve redundancy for the connectivity portion by establishing additional Virtual Cross Connects (VXCs) to the AWS environment and implementing them on separate Ports.

input: Can I create a private Hosted VIF for VMware Cloud on AWS?
output: Yes, customers can create a private Hosted VIF from their account and enter the VMware Cloud on AWS account number for the VIF, which can be obtained from the VMware Cloud on AWS console.

input: How can I establish a connection with Megaport if I'm not a current customer?
output: If you're not a current Megaport customer, you can establish a connection by procuring a 1 Gbps, 10 Gbps, or 100 Gbps circuit to one of Megaport's Points of Presence (PoPs) around the globe.

input: What are the available AWS regions for VMware Cloud on AWS?
output: The available AWS regions for VMware Cloud on AWS include US East (N. Virginia), US East (Ohio), US West (N. California), US West (Oregon), Asia Pacific (Sydney), Asia Pacific (Tokyo), Europe (Frankfurt), Europe (Ireland), Europe (London), and AWS GovCloud (US).

input: Can I use Megaport to connect my on-premises infrastructure to VMware Cloud on AWS?
output: Yes, you can use Megaport as your Network-as-a-Service provider to seamlessly deploy Virtual Interfaces (VIF) to AWS Direct Connect for connecting your on-premises infrastructure to VMware Cloud on AWS.

input: What are the requirements for vMotion in the VMware Cloud on AWS environment?
output: For vMotion between a VMkernel source and destination in the VMware Cloud on AWS environment, a minimum bandwidth of 250 Mbps is required with a maximum round trip latency of 150 ms.

input: What is a Virtual Cross Connect (VXC)?

input: How can I connect to services on the Megaport network with MVE?
output: With MVE, you can create VXCs without the need for physical infrastructure.

input: What is the purpose of VLAN ID in a VXC?

input: What are the three parts to adding a Google Cloud connection to your MVE and vManage?

input: What do you need to provide when setting up the Google Cloud connection in the Megaport Portal?
