output: Invited users will receive an introductory email with information about accessing the Megaport Portal and a temporary password.

input: What should invited users do upon their first login to the Megaport Portal?
output: Upon first login, invited users need to set a new password that meets the minimum security requirements.

input: What happens if Single Sign-On (SSO) is enabled for an account?
output: If SSO is enabled and the email domain is associated with a registered SSO domain, invited users must click a link in the email to confirm their account.

input: Can invited users log in without clicking the confirmation link?
output: Invited users will not be able to log in if they have not clicked the confirmation link in the email.

input: How can invited users be deleted if they do not activate their account?
output: Company Admin users can delete invited users if they haven't activated their account and changed their password.

input: What happens when a Google user is invited to an account?
output: A Google user will receive a temporary password and needs to log in directly through a username and password to create their account.

input: What can Company Admin users do to invite other users?
output: Company Admin users can visit the Megaport Portal, go to Company > Manage Users, and click on New User to invite other users.

input: What fields need to be completed when inviting a user to the account?
output: When inviting a user, Company Admin users need to provide the first name, last name, email, phone number, and select a Megaport user role.

input: What happens when SSO is enabled and the email domain is associated with SSO?
output: Invited users will receive an email with a link to confirm their account if SSO is enabled and the email domain is associated with SSO.

input: Can users from other domains be added to the account?
output: Users from other domains can be added, but they won't be able to log in unless they are given the Company Admin role.

input: How can invited users be deleted from the account?
output: Company Admin users can visit the Megaport Portal, go to Company > Manage Users, locate the user, and click Delete if they haven't logged in.

input: Can deleted invited users be re-invited using the same email address?
output: Deleted invited users can be re-invited using the same email address, as long as the initial user marked as Inactive is not re-activated.

input: What happens when you receive an invite as a username and password user?
output: You will receive an invitation email with a link to log in using your email and temporary password, and then you'll be prompted to reset your password.

input: What are the password complexity requirements for the Megaport Portal?
output: The password must be at least 8 characters long and include uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and at least one special character.

input: What should you do if your password doesn't meet the complexity requirements?
output: If your password meets the complexity requirements but is still being rejected, it might be too common or easily guessed.

input: What happens after resetting your password in the Megaport Portal?
output: After resetting your password, you will receive a confirmation prompt, and then you can log in to the Megaport Portal with the new password.

input: How can you accept an invite to your Megaport account with SSO enabled?
output: If you receive an invite for an account with SSO enabled, you can simply click the Complete Account Setup link to confirm your user account.

input: What should you do if you receive an invite email for your Megaport account?
output: You can follow the instructions in the email to either log in with a temporary password or confirm your user account, depending on the email content.

input: How can I verify the status of MVE?
output: You can verify MVE status from the Megaport Portal. On the Services page in the Portal, find the MVE and mouse over its icon. A message displays the status of the service.

input: What is a ping test and how can I perform it on MVE?
output: A ping test transmits data packets to a specific IP address and either confirms or denies connectivity between IP-networked devices. To perform a ping test on MVE, run ping tests from MVE to the MVE default gateway IP address, SD-WAN management server/controller, and a public IP like ns1.google.com or 8.8.8.8.

input: How can I verify the remote access configurations for MVE?
output: To verify MVE remote access configurations, check if MVE status is reachable/up in the SD-WAN management controller and Megaport Portal. Also, check if SSH works and review configurations for different vendors for further troubleshooting.

input: How can I verify a Cisco configuration for MVE?
output: To verify a Cisco configuration for MVE, check if Megaport API call communication is allowed. Ensure internet access is granted for vManage. Review the configuration details in vManage templates and features.

input: How can I verify a Fortinet configuration for MVE?
output: To verify a Fortinet configuration for MVE, ensure SSH access is granted by attempting to connect using SSH to the Fortinet MVE instance. Also, check if HTTPS access is allowed using the 'show system interface' command.

input: How can I verify a Versa configuration for MVE?
output: To verify a Versa configuration for MVE, check the remote access configuration in Versa Director. Review the device template, including the SSH enablement.

input: How can I verify a VMware configuration for MVE?
output: To verify a VMware configuration for MVE, ensure the device configuration is correct in Orchestrator. Enable Cloud VPN, select the appropriate device type, disable specific interfaces, and allow Support Access and Local Web UI Access from specific IP addresses.

input: How can I verify ACL/FW rules on customer devices for MVE?
output: To verify ACL/FW rules on customer devices for MVE, ensure there are no firewalls or ACLs blocking the ping packets between Layer 3 endpoints. Perform checks like examining the egress and ingress interfaces/subinterfaces, and perform a traceroute to identify potential timeouts.

input: What should I do if the troubleshooting actions do not resolve the issue with MVE?
output: If the troubleshooting actions do not resolve your issue with MVE, you should contact support for further assistance. Provide details of all troubleshooting steps taken.

input: What information should I collect before contacting support for assistance with MVE?
output: Before contacting support for assistance with MVE, collect details of all troubleshooting steps taken, including the location and direction of any placed loops.

input: How can I verify the status of MVE using the Megaport Portal?
output: To verify the status of MVE using the Megaport Portal, go to the Services page in the Portal, find the MVE, and mouse over its icon. A message will display the status of the service.

input: How can I perform a ping test on MVE?
output: To perform a ping test on MVE, run ping tests from MVE to the MVE default gateway IP address, SD-WAN management server/controller, and a public IP like ns1.google.com or 8.8.8.8.

input: How can I check if SSH access works on MVE?
output: To check if SSH access works on MVE, attempt to connect using SSH to the MVE instance. Use the appropriate private key generated when ordering and the assigned public IP address. The default username is admin.

input: How can I check if Megaport API call communication is allowed for Cisco configuration?
output: To check if Megaport API call communication is allowed for Cisco configuration, ensure that the vManage console allows this API call. If necessary, open ports on the customer firewall protecting the on-premises vManage.

input: How can I ensure internet access is granted for vManage in Cisco configuration?
output: To ensure internet access is granted for vManage in Cisco configuration, go to Configuration > Templates in vManage, find the applied template, and check the configuration details. Specifically, check if the Cisco VPN Interface Ethernet type has the necessary internet access.

input: How can I check if SSH access is granted for Fortinet configuration?
output: To check if SSH access is granted for Fortinet configuration, attempt to connect using SSH to the Fortinet MVE instance. Use the private key generated when ordering and the assigned public IP address. The default username is admin.

input: How can I check if HTTPS access is allowed for Fortinet configuration?
output: To check if HTTPS access is allowed for Fortinet configuration, SSH into the Fortinet MVE instance and grant HTTPS access. You can verify if access is allowed using the 'show system interface' command.

input: How can I verify the remote access configuration in Versa Director?
output: To verify the remote access configuration in Versa Director, go to the Configuration tab, select Device Templates, find your device template, and click View. Review the configuration details, including the SSH enablement.

input: How can I verify the device configuration in Orchestrator for VMware?
output: To verify the device configuration in Orchestrator for VMware, go to Configure > Profiles, select the applied configuration profile, and click the Device tab. Ensure Cloud VPN is enabled, only the device type for Virtual Edge is selected, and the interfaces GE1 and GE2 are disabled. Also, ensure Support Access and Local Web UI Access from specific IP addresses are allowed.

input: How can I verify ACL/FW rules on customer devices?
output: To verify ACL/FW rules on customer devices, examine the network diagram and traceroute result. Ensure the source device is sending ping packets, the destination device is receiving them, and check the configuration on the intermediate devices. Firewall or ACL settings may cause ping failures while other traffic passes.

input: What should I do if the troubleshooting actions do not resolve the issue with MVE?
output: If the troubleshooting actions do not resolve your issue with MVE, please contact support for further assistance. Be sure to provide details of all troubleshooting steps taken.

input: What information should I collect before contacting support for assistance?
output: Before contacting support for assistance, please collect details of all troubleshooting steps taken, including the location and direction of any placed loops.

input: How do I log in to the Megaport Portal?
output: To log in to the Megaport Portal, visit the Megaport Portal website. Enter your email address and click Continue. If you have multi-factor authentication (MFA) enabled, enter the code from the authenticator app and click Verify. If MFA is not enabled, you may need to set it up during your next login.

input: What is Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)?
output: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) is a security system that requires multiple verification factors to access an account. It ensures enhanced security by combining something you know (e.g., username and password) with something you have (e.g., code from an authentication app). Megaport recommends using the Google Authenticator app for MFA.

input: How do I enable MFA for my Megaport Portal login?
output: To enable MFA for your Megaport Portal login, install a login verification app (such as Google Authenticator) on your digital device. During the login process, you will need to scan a QR code with the authenticator app and enter the one-time token generated by the app. MFA will be enabled for your account after completing these steps.

input: What happens if I enter an incorrect MFA token multiple times?
output: If you enter an incorrect MFA token five times, your account will be locked. To reactivate your account, a Company Admin can go to the Company > Manage Users page on the Megaport Portal and modify your account status.

input: How do I log in after MFA has been reset for my profile?
output: If MFA has been reset for your profile, you need to set up MFA again to log in to the Megaport Portal. Scan the QR code with the authenticator app and enter the new one-time token generated by the app. After enabling MFA, you will need to provide a valid token from the app every time you log in.

input: What is Single Sign-On (SSO)?
output: Single Sign-On (SSO) is an identity and access management solution that allows users to log in once and access multiple applications, websites, and software systems without re-authentication. With SSO, users only need to authenticate their identity once, providing enhanced security and a streamlined user experience.

input: How do I log in to the Megaport Portal using SSO?
output: If your company has enforced SSO, you must use SSO for logging into the Megaport Portal. After entering your email address on the login page, you will be directed to your company's identity provider (IdP) for authentication. Follow the instructions provided by your IdP to complete the login process.

input: Can I remain logged in using SSO?
output: If your identity provider (IdP) offers the option, you can select to remain logged in, eliminating the need for repeated authentication. This option may vary depending on your IdP's settings and policies.

input: How many verification factors are typically required for MFA?
output: Typically, MFA requires at least two verification factors. For example, it could be a combination of a username/password and a code from an authentication app.

input: Which authentication app is recommended for MFA?
output: Megaport recommends using the Google Authenticator app for MFA. It provides a secure and convenient way to generate one-time tokens for the authentication process.

input: What should I do if I experience login issues?
output: If you are experiencing issues logging in, click on the 'Get help signing in' option on the login page for assistance.

input: What is the purpose of MFA in the Megaport Portal?
output: MFA adds an extra layer of security to your Megaport Portal account by requiring multiple verification factors for authentication. It helps protect your account from unauthorized access and ensures a stronger identity and access management (IAM) policy.

input: Can I log in to the Megaport Portal without enabling MFA?
output: If your Company Admin has enforced MFA globally, you will need to set up MFA during your next login. Enabling MFA is recommended to enhance the security of your Megaport Portal account.

input: How can I manage my MFA settings?
output: You can manage your MFA settings by following the instructions provided in the 'Securing your account with MFA' documentation. It provides details on how to enable, disable, or modify your MFA settings.

input: What happens if my MFA code is reset by a Company Admin?
output: If a Company Admin resets your MFA code, you will need to set up MFA again to log in. The previous MFA codes will no longer be valid, and you must scan the QR code with the authenticator app to generate new codes.

input: What are the benefits of using SSO?
output: Using SSO offers improved security for organizations and a better user experience. It allows users to log in once and access multiple services without the need for repeated authentication. Administrators can also more easily manage user identity and access across different applications.

input: Do I need to authenticate multiple times when using SSO?
output: No, with Single Sign-On (SSO), you only need to authenticate once. After your identity is validated, you can access multiple applications and services without the need for repeated authentication.

input: How does SSO benefit administrators?
output: SSO simplifies user identity and access management for administrators. They can easily manage user access to multiple applications and websites from a centralized system, reducing the administrative burden and enhancing security.

input: Can I log in to the Megaport Portal without using SSO?
output: If your company has enforced Single Sign-On (SSO), you must use SSO for logging in to the Megaport Portal. It offers a streamlined login process and ensures consistent access control across your organization.

input: Where can I find further setup instructions and help with SSO?
output: Please refer to your identity provider's website for further setup instructions, troubleshooting assistance, and information about their privacy policies.

input: How can I check for errors and packet drops on the device?
output: You can check interface statistics and logs on the device to identify the cause of the fault.

input: What should I do if no signal is received from the far-end device?
output: If no signal is received, it could indicate that the polarity is wrong and reversed. Verify the fiber polarity.

input: What tests should be performed by the data center?
output: The data center should check the cross connect for damages or cleaning, ensure adequate light transmission, and verify SFP models align with specifications.

input: What should be validated in terms of equipment performance?
output: Customers should validate the performance of hardware, optic, port capacity, switch, router, firewall models, firmware version, traffic flow, port utilization, CPU utilization, configuration, and overall network design.

input: How can I compare my latency to Megaport's published latency?
output: Watch a 1-minute video on how to compare your latency.

input: What is traceroute and how can it help with troubleshooting?
output: Traceroute is a diagnostic tool that examines how data moves through the internet and helps determine if a destination is reachable. It measures transit delays and shows the route packets take.

input: What should I provide when contacting support for assistance?
output: Provide troubleshooting results, source and destination IP addresses, a high-level network diagram, ping test results, and traceroute results.

input: What should I do if the troubleshooting actions do not resolve my issue?
output: Contact Megaport support and provide all the relevant information and steps you have taken.

input: How can I request a field service technician onsite at the data center?
output: Refer to Customer Field Services for details on requesting a field service technician.

input: What route is MCR currently using to send traffic?
output: The Looking Glass can provide information about the current route being used by MCR to send traffic.

input: What are all possible routes MCR can use?
output: The Looking Glass can display all possible routes that MCR can use for forwarding traffic.

input: What IP prefixes and routes have I received from my BGP neighbor(s)?
output: The Looking Glass can show the IP prefixes and routes received from BGP neighbors.

input: Which routes have been advertised to my BGP neighbor(s)?
output: The Looking Glass can provide information about the routes that have been advertised to BGP neighbors.

input: Does a route exist in the routing table for a specific destination?
output: The Looking Glass can check if a specific destination has a route in the routing table.

input: How can I access the services available through the Looking Glass?
output: Megaport offers a public API that can be used to access the services available through the Looking Glass. Details can be found in the Megaport API documentation.

input: How can I view the Looking Glass?
output: To view the Looking Glass, log in to the Megaport Portal, go to Services, and select MCR Looking Glass from the Tools menu. Alternatively, you can click the binoculars icon next to an MCR for easy access.

input: What information does the BGP Sessions section provide?
output: The BGP Sessions section in the Looking Glass displays all the BGP sessions configured on the Virtual Cross Connects (VXCs) for the selected MCR.

input: What does the Routing Table display?
output: The Routing Table in the Looking Glass provides an overview of the networks that MCR can reach, including static, local, connected, and BGP routes. MCR consults this table when selecting the best route for forwarding traffic.

input: How many routes are displayed per page in the Routing Table?
output: The number of routes displayed per page in the Routing Table can be changed using the drop-down list at the bottom of the table. By default, it shows 20 routes per page.

input: What is the purpose of BGP sessions?
output: BGP sessions allow communication between neighboring routers using a standard TCP connection. BGP neighbors share routing information with each other through these sessions.

input: How can I search for routes within a specific BGP session?
output: In the Looking Glass, you can search for routes within a specific BGP session by typing an IP address or text in the search box and clicking on Neighbour Routes to open a new tab for that session.

input: What do the status icons in VXC details indicate?
output: The status icons in VXC details indicate the current BGP session status. A green check mark signifies that the session is up, a red x means the session is down, and a yellow information icon indicates an unknown status.

input: How does MCR select the best route for forwarding traffic?
output: MCR uses a combination of metrics received from BGP neighbors and its own settings to determine the best route for forwarding traffic. It also follows BGP policies and autonomous system (AS) routing best practices.

input: What does the Static Routes section display?
output: The Static Routes section in the Looking Glass shows manually defined routes that are not part of a routing protocol. These routes are entered and maintained manually.

input: How can I view all the BGP routes in the BGP Table?
output: To view all the BGP routes in the BGP Table, select the BGP Table tab in the Looking Glass and choose All Routes.

input: What are the BGP route attributes displayed in the BGP route details?
output: The BGP route attributes displayed in the BGP route details include the AS path, local preference, Multi-Exit Discriminator, origin, and communities.

input: What is the purpose of the BGP community attribute?
output: The BGP community attribute is used to group destinations that share a common property. It is represented as As-number:community-value, where As-number identifies a BGP network and community-value specifies the property.

input: How can I reload the route information in the Looking Glass?
output: To reload the route information in the Looking Glass, click on the Reload Data button in the upper-right corner.

input: What is the purpose of the Looking Glass in troubleshooting connections?
output: The Looking Glass provides single-screen visibility into traffic routing and helps troubleshoot connections by showing the status of protocols and routing tables in MCR.

input: How can I create a VXC connection from an MCR to AWS?
output: To create a VXC connection from an MCR to AWS, you need to follow the steps outlined in the Megaport Portal. Make sure you have the necessary prerequisites and select the appropriate connection type based on your requirements.

input: What are the prerequisites for creating a private virtual interface to connect an MCR to AWS?
output: To create a private connection from an MCR to AWS, you need to have your AWS Account number, an AWS virtual private gateway or Direct Connect gateway associated with your VPCs, and the ASN number for the AWS gateway.

input: Can I connect my MCR to public resources in AWS?
output: Yes, you can create a public virtual interface to connect your MCR to public resources such as Amazon S3 and Amazon DynamoDB. Megaport provides a /31 range for public peering and for the global AWS route tables.

input: What is a transit virtual interface?
output: A transit virtual interface allows you to establish a connection from an MCR to AWS using an AWS transit gateway.

input: What are the different connection types for connecting an MCR to AWS?
output: There are two connection types: Hosted VIF and Hosted Connection. Hosted VIFs can connect to public or private AWS cloud services, while Hosted Connections can support one private, public, or transit virtual interface.

input: How do I create a Hosted VIF connection from an MCR to AWS?
output: To create a Hosted VIF connection, you need to select the MCR in the Megaport Portal, choose AWS as the service provider, select Hosted VIF as the AWS Connection Type, and provide the necessary connection details.

input: What is the process for accepting a private virtual interface for MCR to AWS connections?
output: After ordering a private Hosted VIF VXC, you can review and accept the corresponding inbound VIF request in the AWS Direct Connect > Virtual Interfaces page in the AWS console. The VIF should match the configuration details provided in the Megaport Portal.

input: How long does it take to verify and accept a public virtual interface for MCR to AWS connections?
output: The verification process for a public virtual interface can take up to 72 hours. After ordering a public Hosted VIF VXC, you can review and accept the corresponding inbound VIF request in the AWS Direct Connect > Virtual Interfaces page in the AWS console.

input: Can a user's access be suspended in the Megaport Portal?

input: What are the benefits of connecting to Cloudflare through Megaport?
output: The benefits of direct connectivity to Cloudflare through Megaport include private access that bypasses the public internet, high performance and predictability for your network, improved data and operational security, flexible and scalable cloud networking, consistent connectivity while scaling bandwidth to Cloudflare, and the ability to connect to multiple regions from a single interconnection point.

input: Where is Cloudflare Network Interconnect available with Megaport?
output: Cloudflare Network Interconnect is available in Asia Pacific (Singapore, Sydney, Tokyo), Europe (Amsterdam, Frankfurt, London), and North America (Ashburn, Chicago, Los Angeles, Miami, New York City, San Jose, Seattle, Toronto).

input: What are the prerequisites for connecting to Cloudflare through Megaport?
output: Before connecting, you need to notify Cloudflare and ensure you have a Megaport connection with a 1 Gbps or 10 Gbps Port or an MCR. Public ASNs are also required.

input: How can I create a connection to Cloudflare through Megaport?
output: The easiest way to create a connection is with a service key obtained from Cloudflare. In the Megaport Portal, you can enter the service key, provide connection details such as a connection name and rate limit, and deploy a VXC connection to Cloudflare.

input: How can I establish redundancy between my data center and Cloudflare?
output: To establish full redundancy, it is recommended to deploy redundant VXCs between two different Cloudflare regions (or availability zones within a region) and two corresponding Ports at each Megaport-enabled data center.

input: Does Cloudflare support BYOIP (Bring Your Own IP)?
output: Yes, Cloudflare is a public service, so you can use your own public IPs.

input: What type of ASNs does Cloudflare support?
output: Cloudflare supports public ASNs. If you are using a public ASN, you must own it as Cloudflare will verify ownership for Magic Transit before announcing network routes.

input: What additional resources are available for connecting to Cloudflare with Megaport?
output: Additional resources include an infopaper on connecting to Cloudflare with Megaport, Cloudflare Enterprise Services, Cloudflare DDoS protection, Cloudflare CDN, and Cloudflare Magic Transit.

input: How can I contact Cloudflare to obtain a service key?
output: You can contact Cloudflare directly to obtain a service key.

input: What are the available locations for Cloudflare Network Interconnect with Megaport in the Asia Pacific region?
output: The available locations in the Asia Pacific region are Singapore (Equinix SG1), Sydney (Equinix SY 1/2), and Tokyo (Equinix TY2).

input: What are the available locations for Cloudflare Network Interconnect with Megaport in the Europe region?
output: The available locations in the Europe region are Amsterdam (Equinix AM1), Frankfurt (Equinix FR5), and London (Telehouse North).

input: What are the available locations for Cloudflare Network Interconnect with Megaport in the North America region?
output: The available locations in the North America region are Ashburn (Equinix DC/6), Chicago (Equinix CH1/2/4), Los Angeles (Equinix LA1), Miami (Equinix MI1), New York City (Digital Realty NYC2), San Jose (Equinix SV1/5/10), Seattle (Equinix SE2), and Toronto (Equinix TY2).

input: Can I connect to multiple Cloudflare regions using a single interconnection point?
output: Yes, with Megaport, you can connect to multiple regions from a single interconnection point, leveraging multi-region redundancy at a fraction of the cost.

input: What are the benefits of private access to Cloudflare through Megaport?
output: Private access bypasses the public internet, providing improved data and operational security, high performance and predictability for your network, and flexible and scalable cloud networking.

input: What are the benefits of using Megaport for connecting to Cloudflare?
output: Using Megaport for connecting to Cloudflare offers private access, high performance, improved security, flexible and scalable cloud networking, consistent connectivity while scaling bandwidth, and cost-effective multi-region redundancy.

input: What services are provided by Cloudflare in addition to Cloudflare Network Interconnect?
output: Cloudflare services include Magic Transit, authenticated origin pulls for large CDN customers, and Cloudflare for Teams.

input: What are the available Port capacities for connecting to Cloudflare through Megaport?
output: You can create a 1 Gbps or 10 Gbps Port onto the Megaport network. Limited locations also offer 100 Gbps Ports.

input: What is an MCR and how is it used for connecting to Cloudflare?
output: An MCR enables data transfer between multi-cloud and hybrid cloud environments, network service providers, and cloud service providers. It can be used for connecting to Cloudflare.

input: What is a service key and how is it used to create a connection between Megaport and Cloudflare?
output: A service key includes the essential configuration details and automates much of the configuration process when creating a connection between Megaport and Cloudflare. It can be obtained from Cloudflare.

input: What steps are involved in creating a VXC connection to Cloudflare through Megaport?
output: The steps include obtaining a service key from Cloudflare, entering the key in the Megaport Portal, providing connection details such as a connection name and rate limit, and deploying the VXC connection.
